channel.title: Spring JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SGF-497] Intermittent failures in DurableClientCacheIntegrationTest
item.description:
The IO 2.1 compatibility build is failing due to a problem with DurableClientCacheIntegrationTest durableClientGetsUpdatesFromServerWhileClientWasOffline. It sometimes fails when run against Java 7 and sometimes fails when run against Java 8 so it appears to be somewhat intermittent. The failure is:

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: And interestingly enough, the DurableClientCacheIntegrationTest class passes consistently in the CI env (both Nightly-NoMocks and Nightly-WithMocks). The "mock" build is a JDK8 build. This test has consistently passed since it it's inception.

Another thing to be aware of, is if any previous build failures left any lingering (forked (GemFire)) processes, this might adversely affect subsequent runs. However, each SD GemFire (integration) test (class) makes a best effort to cleanup after the tests run.

One potential problem, particularly if tests fail from previous build/test runs and leave lingering (forked (GemFire)) processes behind, is that the client/server port is hard coded. I will change this test to use dynamic, "available" port generation per run using the core Spring Framework's SocketUtils class.

Let's see if this improves the outcome. Unfortunately, I am not sure if much else can be done, especially if the client/server GemFire (client/server) processes are unique and paired appropriately. It is possible GemFire has a race condition that is preventing the client's durable queue from being updated by the cache client producer appropriately, before the "original", durable client re-connects. I will try to think of and explore other alternatives.
I made some changes to this test to hopefully improve upon it's reliability. Please feel free to re-open this ticket if you continue to have trouble.

Unfortunately, the failure still occurs. After further investigation, I can reliably reproduce the failure using Java 7 (1.7.0_79) and the project's default versions, i.e. without any involvement from the Platform. To do so, I:

  • Checked out master (9e61270c)
  • Ran `./gradlew eclipse`
  • Imported `spring-data-gemfire` into Eclipse as an existing project
  • Ran DurableClientCacheIntegrationTest in Eclipse using Java 7 (1.7.0_79)

durableClientGetsInitializedWithDataOnServer passes and then durableClientGetsUpdatesFromServerWhileClientWasOffline fails:

java.lang.IllegalStateException: Failed to load ApplicationContext

Usually I prefer to build/ test with Gradle/Maven on the command-line. I do not use Gradle's Eclipse or IDEA plugins to generate settings for my IDE (IntelliJ IDEA). I rather prefer to import the Gradle build file into IDEA directly, then I build and run isolated, component-based tests.

I just realized I had not installed JDK 7 since getting my new machine. I tried to download some time ago, but Oracle locked me out of my "customer" account, which is needed to access JDK 7 updates and downloads not due to EOL.

Anyway, I was finally able to restore my account, download/install JDK 7, and reproduce the issue. Let me investigate this further. This is not a problem under JRE 8, but for some reason, GemFire is having a problem with JRE 7, o.O.

FYI, I do have a SDG CI build for both JDK 7 and JDK 8.
Alright, this should be fixed now. SDG builds successfully on both JDK 7 and JDK 8 with a language compatibility level set to Java 6.
